node.title: Israel Passes First Budget in More Than 3 Years
node.alt: A session and vote on the state budget at Israelâ€™s Parliament in Jerusalem on Wednesday.
node.description: The vote raised hopes that the country might be headed for increased political stability after the chaos of four elections in quick succession.
node.content: ["JERUSALEM \u2014 Israel\u2019s Parliament narrowly approved a state budget on Thursday, the country\u2019s first in more than three years, removing an imminent threat to the survival of the government and potentially paving the way to some political stability after a chaotic stretch of four elections within two years.", "\u201cA holiday for the state of Israel!\u201d Prime Minister Naftali Bennett exulted on Twitter shortly after the pre-dawn vote. \u201cWe are moving ahead with full force.\u201d", "But the razor-thin majority eked out by Mr. Bennett\u2019s coalition of eight parties with clashing ideologies and agendas raised questions about its longer-term prospects and whether Israel has truly emerged from years of political morass.", "The vote on the annual budget for what is left of 2021 passed by a vote of 61 to 59 in the 120-seat Knesset, or Parliament, with no abstentions.", "It was approved after a marathon debate that included a four-hour speech by a filibustering member of the opposition. A 60:60 draw would have meant failure, and failure to pass a budget by a Nov. 14 deadline would have led to the automatic dissolution of the Parliament and new elections within three months, which was the goal of an opposition faction led by Mr. Bennett\u2019s predecessor, Benjamin Netanyahu.", "Voting on a budget for 2022 was expected to conclude late Thursday or on Friday."]
